@unclelukereal1 WAY WAY MORE needs to be done, and if you follow me you see my consistent critiques of the system. But we only win when we organize together and hold elected officials accountable with consistent engagement and direct action. DM me @unclelukereal1 to chat more about this.

@unclelukereal1 But voting is not enough. To ensure Black people get what we deserve we have to be organizing in our living rooms everyday. And we have to strategically plan and invest in changing the political, social and economic system in a way that helps Black people to thrive.

@unclelukereal1 When you don’t vote you can’t elect the people who make decisions on your behalf and you can’t build long term structural power. You can’t pick judges, you can’t authorize spending, you can’t change the institutions that continue to harm Black people.

@unclelukereal1 My office:
1. Expand harm reduction programs for Black children
2. Expand mental health supports for Black seniors 
3. Passed a bill to support Black veterans access to health care 
4. Provide grant funding to YMCAa and B&G clubs 
5. Show up and listen to my constituents

@unclelukereal1 The US Govt 
1.The ARP made historic investments in black school districts 
2. Kentanji Brown Jackson 
3. I am the first black man to hold this seat in US history 
4. The ARP cut black child poverty of 34% 
5. Authorizing historic investment in minority business development

Also, that #Taiwan wasn’t invited is unconscionable. Taiwan is a high-standards economy & one of our top trading partners. Its inclusion in what amounts to an economic club would have greatly benefited each of the IPEF’s pillars. Leaving Taiwan out is a needless bow to the #CCP.

The biggest problem with the IPEF is that the Administration failed to include market access provisions, which is what the region really wants, and which would have given us something to offer in exchange for advancing the interests of American workers and businesses.

But there are major problems with IPEF. First, the Administration has been working on the IPEF for months now, but today’s announcement said that members would start “discussions toward future negotiations.” In other words, at this point we are just talking about talking.

Therefore, it’s good to see that in addition to the United States, the IPEF will include Australia, Brunei, India, Indonesia, Japan, Republic of Korea, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam, which collectively make up 40% of global GDP.

The Indo-Pacific has 60% of global population and will be the top driver of the world’s economic growth for decades to come. It’s absolutely critical that the United States shows economic leadership in a region on which our economic future will increasingly depend.

China is setting the trade rules in the Indo-Pacific to the detriment of American consumers and businesses. The President’s announcement today of the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework is a welcome step to get us back in the game, but the framework leaves much to be desired.
